title: R41839
content: The Dodd-Frank Act established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau within the Federal Reserve System, consolidating regulatory authority in one regulator. The Bureau will oversee various consumer financial products and services. The CFPB will have supervisory and enforcement authority over a wide range of consumer financial products and services, including deposit taking, mortgage lending, credit card lending, loan servicing, debt collection, and more. It will serve as the primary federal consumer financial supervisor for many institutions offering these services and can prescribe regulations to implement existing consumer laws. The CFPB, as the primary federal consumer financial supervisor, will have authority to implement existing consumer laws like TILA and RESPA. Some of its powers took effect when Dodd-Frank was signed in 2010, with others to follow. The CFPB's powers became effective at different times, with most authorities set to go into effect on the designated transfer date of July 21, 2011.
